text: the internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of this new
Algiers album shook this is the fourth
full-length LP from radical Georgia
rockers Algiers one of my favorite bands
to break out of the 2010s these guys
brought a unique blend of Blues
goth-tinged Gospel and post-punk that
resulted in two of the most
underappreciated albums of the past
decade in my opinion then there was
their third record there is no year
which for sure is more interesting than
most stuff out there these days but it
was still their weakest effort yet in my
opinion was it due to stagnance or maybe
the band trying to streamline their
sound to make it more accessible I'm not
entirely sure either way it led to an
album with fewer bold instrumentals
highlights and surprises but now in 2023
we have a follow-up with shook where I
think Algiers is kind of taking the
opposite approach this time around the
band is getting even Wilder and more
ambitious with their genre fusions now
though I think their plan to do that was
already made clear with teasers
featuring guest rap verses from Billy
Woods backwash and Rage Against the
Machines Zack de la Rocha shook also
doesn't hesitate to dive further into
more analog synthesizers sequenced
electronic beats so the band is bringing
even more sounds and ideas into their
already eclectic mix of everything so
the question really is does it pay off
and for me that's difficult to say while
shook is definitely not all bangers I
can respect that this is likely going to
be the most unruly album Algiers will
ever release because the tracklist on
this thing is a bumpy white water raft
adventure of surprise guests weird
musical sidebars interludes anthems
Odysseys and hair brained ideas to call
the flow of this thing choppy would be a
bit of an understatement one thing about
this record is super clear though and
that's Algiers political leanings which
they expel pretty creatively throughout
this album through some of the guest
spots through phone recordings through
poetry the spoken word appearance from
Atlanta Legend big rube makes for quite
the album tone Setter on the intro track
so there's that there's the messaging
but everything else about the album in
terms of style structure song quality is
a bit more of a crap shoot now here and
there this volatility does lead to some
highlights we have irreversible damage
with Zach de la Rocha who I mentioned
earlier which features some intensely
twittering beats murderously sour chord
changes some hellish layers of guitars
and Howling vocals too frontman Franklin
James Fisher has one of the most fiery
and dynamic vocal performances on any
algier song with a seamless mix of
singing shouting and rapping that makes
way more sense than it should Zach's
appearance is solid per usual and
there's an explosive ending on the track
that's fantastic too deeper into the
record we also have the punk rager a
good man The Haunting and Soulful I
Can't Stand It featuring Sam T hearing a
future islands Fame then there's also
the Grimrock Anthem cold world which has
some pretty cool industrial undertones
to it the aggressive vocal chance on
this one make it a high highlight along
with the unique vocal performance from
Egyptian artist NADA El shazley 73
percent is another favorite on the
record it is a groovy piece of art Punk
with a lot of spoken word passages laced
into it it's a pretty dense song that
says a lot but ultimately it boils down
to society's willingness to blame each
other blame the perilous blame the
marginalized for the problems in the
world we live in as opposed to the
ruling class or those in power who are
actually like in charge of fixing these
things so yeah I love those tracks on
the lp but the rest of the album more or
less leaves me cold or scratching my
head for a variety of different reasons
there are some tracks that have a severe
lack of development to them most notably
cleanse your guilt here whose Moody
vocals and looping Soul chops have
potential to them that isn't fully
explored there's bite back with Billy
Woods and backwash which I wasn't really
crazy about as a single I'm still sort
of on the fence with it mostly because
it does feel like a hodgepodge of
different passages and ideas also
Fisher's rap verse in the middle of the
track is not really all that well done
like there's clearly a gap in quality in
terms of flow and energy going on here
when it's sandwiched in between Billy
Woods and backwash plus there's a few
awkward musical transitions from the
start to the finish of the cut too
because the track while yes it does
present a lot within the six minutes it
lasts the end result isn't really all
that potent it comes across more
disjointed than cohesive but I I suppose
the ending is still pretty strong there
are also cuts on this thing like an
echophonic Soul or out of style tragedy
which more or less are spoken word
pieces which I could really take or
leave especially since the Poetry kind
of melts into the dense instrumentals
here and doesn't really keep me on the
edge of my seat these songs come across
like filler filler I would like to look
past but they take up so much real
estate in the album's run time because
sadly on this almost hour-long album
Algiers does sink a lot of effort into
these Bridges to Nowhere or uh tracks
that I think are Half Baked but somehow
go on forever like the song Green Iris
which might be my least favorite here
which features some very over-the-top
gospel Harmony layers uh some minimal
hand claps very very very tense jazz
chord changes too and all of it really
just feels like a mismatch honestly
especially when you take into account
the very aggressive shift into latter
instrumentation and electronic Beats at
the very end which kind of comes across
like too little too late which I also
felt on the song something wrong which
in concept is a really promising Rock
Cut about an exchange that you would
have with an officer as you're just
being pulled over given that it's an
Algiers album I think we know how this
is going to play out and rather than
just letting the commentary on this
track be what it's going to be and see
whether or not it just kind of stands on
the Merit of however it's performed or
pulled off Algiers decides to just slow
the whole track down and just throw the
pitch off and soak what's left in W
effects and droning synthesizers now I
do like that the tempo picks back up at
the very finish which is very vengeful
but the journey to get to that point is
very long and very obnoxious I don't
really have much else to say about this
record other than it's kind of odd to be
at this point because Algiers really did
hit us with a very different album this
time around and despite that I somehow
don't feel that much stronger about it
than I did there is no year because for
sure there are some solid songs on the
album here and there but quite a few
tracks on this thing are dedicated to
fragments and underdeveloped ideas so
while shook is certainly adventurous
it's also really unfocused in a way now
ultimately I can't say I'm really
surprised by this change and this level
of experimentation from Algiers we are
talking about the band that dropped a
can the sub bass speak a jazz poetry
sound collage which if you remember was
like the first single from their album
cycle the track didn't even end up
making it on to the album but given the
tone and style of that track I was
expecting uh more songs like that to end
up on that LP now finally we have Shook
and there are multiple tracks here that
I would I would say are more along the
lines of of that single stylistically
and in a way this album embodies that
energy in totality it is a chaotic
collage of ideas and sounds and styles
and structures and approaches which just
thrives on its messaging and its
Rebellion against being neatly
categorized while I think Algiers
rebellious attitude have served them
well in the past it led to a lack of
musical coherence and cohesion this time
around in my opinion I'm feeling a
decent too strong six on this one
transition have you given this album a
listen did you love it did you hate it
what would you rate it you're the best
or the best what should I review next
